metadata.titleEn: National survey data of manure nutrient input to cropland across China from 2005 to 2014
metadata.description: The data included the inputs of manure nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P), and potassium (K) for cereals, fruits, vegetables, and other crops, along with the manure proportion of total N, P, and K inputs at the county level. The national survey data of > 6.6 million farmers were collected from 2005 to 2014. the total manure N, P, and K input to the cropland for each crop type was extensively quantified at the county level. Second, based on county-level statistical data, the manure inputs for the four crop types were calculated. Finally, in combination with chemical fertilizer input data from the national survey, the county-level spatial variation of the proportion of manure input was established. Our results provide a clear perspective for manure nutrient management in agricultural production, as well as detailed support for environmental impact assessment at the spatial level in China.
metadata.instructions:
A national survey of 6.6 million farmers in 2,013 counties was conducted from 2005 to 2014.Information regarding chemical N, P, and K and manure application rates was used in this study. First, the farmers were divided into four groups according to crop type: cereals, fruits, vegetables, and others; the total manure N, P, and K input to the cropland for each crop type was extensively quantified at the county level. Second, based on county-level statistical data, the manure inputs for the four crop types were calculated. Finally, in combination with chemical fertilizer input data from the national survey, the county-level spatial variation of the proportion of manure input was established.

The datasets were obtained in Excel file format with the following four sheets: “manure N”, “manure P”, “manure K”, and “manure percentage”. The first three sheets described the inputs (unit: tons) of manure N, P, and K into cropland, respectively; the last sheet provided the manure proportions of total nutrient input. These datasets contained the following fields: ProvCode, representing the provincial administrative division code; PAC2015, representing the 2015 county-level administrative division code, obtained from the Ministry of Civil Affairs of the People’s Republic of China; and “TM_Cereals”, “TM_Fruits”, “TM_Vegetables”, and “TM_Others” corresponding to the total manure N, P, and K inputs for the four crop types. In the sheet “manure percentage,” “Mprop_N”, “Mprop_P”, and “Mprop_K” were the manure nutrient proportions of total N, P, and K inputs, respectively. Blank fields indicated municipal districts and some counties without cropland.

Here, we provide vector layers of China’s county-level administrative divisions, packaged in a compressed file called “ChinaCounty”; all results can be revealed by matching the shared PAC2015 field in the layers and Excel datasets.

literatureList.titleEn: Comprehensive assessment of the utilization of manure in China’s croplands based on national survey data
literatureList.referenceEn: Zhang Qingsong, Chu Yiyan, Yin Yulong, Ying Hao, Zhang Fusuo & Cui Zhenling.(2023) Comprehensive assessment of the utilization of manure in China’s croplands based on national survey data. Scientific Data 10, 223 . https://doi.org/10.1038/s41597-023-02154-7

background: China's rapid increase in mass excreta and its environmental discharge have attracted substantial attention. However, cropland as a main destination of excreta utilization has not been extensively evaluated.
research objective: Here, a national survey was used to assess the utilization of manure in croplands across China.
methods: First, the farmers were divided into four groups according to crop type: cereals, fruits, vegetables, and others; the total manure N, P, and K input to the cropland for each crop type was extensively quantified at the county level. Second, based on county-level statistical data, the manure inputs for the four crop types were calculated. Finally, in combination with chemical fertilizer input data from the national survey, the county-level spatial variation of the proportion of manure input was established.
dataset: The data included the inputs of manure nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P), and potassium (K) for cereals, fruits, vegetables, and other crops, along with the manure proportion of total N, P, and K inputs at the county level.
findings: The results showed that the manure N, P, and K inputs were 6.85, 2.14, and 4.65 million tons (Mt), respectively, constituting 19.0%, 25.5%, and 31.1% of the total N, P, and K, respectively. The spatial distribution of the manure proportion of total inputs was lower in Eastern China and higher in Western China. The results provide a detailed description of the utilization of manure nutrients in agricultural areas throughout China, which will serve as basic support for policymakers and researchers involved in future agricultural nutrient management in China.

Verification.Question: Does the data collection method involve dividing farmers into groups based on crop type?
Is the spatial variation of manure input at the county level established using chemical fertilizer input data?
Are the manure nutrient inputs quantified for cereals, fruits, vegetables, and other crops?

Disjunctive.Question: Which method is more effective for quantifying manure nutrient inputs at the county level, direct farmer surveys or statistical data analysis?
Are the challenges in collecting national survey data more related to data accuracy, farmer participation, or logistical issues?
Disjunctive.Answer: data accuracy, farmer participation, or logistical issues

Concept Completion.Question: Who were the main participants involved in the data collection for assessing manure nutrient input to cropland across China?
Concept Completion.Answer: more than 6.6 million farmers across China

Concept Completion.Question: Where does the spatial distribution of manure proportion of total nutrient inputs tend to be higher in China?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to quantify manure nutrient inputs at the county level in China between 2005 and 2014?
Example.Answer: One example of a data collection method is dividing farmers into groups based on crop types (cereals, fruits, vegetables, and others) and quantifying the total manure nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P), and potassium (K) input to cropland for each crop type at the county level using national survey data from over 6.6 million farmers.

Example.Question: What is an example of a dataset that includes spatial variation of manure nutrient input in agricultural production across China?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset includes inputs of manure nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P), and potassium (K) for cereals, fruits, vegetables, and other crops, along with the manure proportion of total N, P, and K inputs at the county level, showing spatial distribution differences across regions such as lower proportions in Eastern China and higher in Western China.

Feature Specification.Question: What characteristics define the data collection techniques used for obtaining manure nutrient input information at a national level?
Feature Specification.Answer: national survey, over 6.6 million farmers, manure nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P), potassium (K) inputs, various crop types, county level, spatial variation in manure input proportions

Feature Specification.Question: What are the specific features that contribute to the spatial variation of manure nutrient inputs across different regions in China?
Feature Specification.Answer: distribution of manure N, P, and K inputs, lower in Eastern China, higher in Western China

Quantification.Question: What is the total number of farmers surveyed to quantify manure nutrient inputs to cropland in China from 2005 to 2014?
How many crop types were considered when calculating the manure nutrient inputs at the county level?
What proportion of the total nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium inputs were contributed by manure according to the national survey data?

Definition.Question: What does 'county-level statistical data' refer to in the context of manure nutrient input assessment?
Definition.Answer: County-level statistical data refers to the aggregated data collected at the county level that is used to calculate manure inputs for different crop types. It helps establish the spatial variation of manure input proportions when combined with chemical fertilizer input data.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'manure proportion of total N, P, and K inputs' at the county level?
Definition.Answer: The 'manure proportion of total N, P, and K inputs' at the county level indicates the percentage of total nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P), and potassium (K) inputs that come from manure, compared to other sources such as chemical fertilizers, for different crop types.

Definition.Question: How is the 'county-level spatial variation of the proportion of manure input' established in manure nutrient management?
Definition.Answer: The 'county-level spatial variation of the proportion of manure input' is established by quantifying the manure nutrient inputs for each crop type and combining this data with chemical fertilizer input data from a national survey, allowing for an analysis of how the proportion of manure input varies across different counties.

Interpretation.Question: How can the spatial variation in manure nutrient inputs across different regions of China be interpreted in terms of environmental impact and agricultural practices?
Interpretation.Answer: The spatial distribution of the manure proportion of total inputs was lower in Eastern China and higher in Western China, suggesting that environmental impact and agricultural practices vary regionally. This variation provides insights into how different regions utilize manure nutrients in agriculture, which can inform environmental impact assessments and nutrient management strategies.

Interpretation.Question: What can be inferred about the methodological rigor of data collection when quantifying manure nutrient inputs at the county level?
Interpretation.Answer: The data collection method involved a national survey of over 6.6 million farmers, categorizing them by crop type and quantifying manure nutrient inputs at the county level. This extensive data collection approach suggests high methodological rigor, enabling detailed spatial analysis and providing a robust foundation for understanding manure nutrient management across China.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the spatial variation in manure nutrient inputs across different regions in China?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The spatial distribution of manure proportion of total inputs was influenced by regional differences, with lower proportions in Eastern China and higher in Western China. These variations could be due to differences in farming practices, regional policies, and the availability of manure resources.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the underlying reasons for integrating chemical fertilizer data with manure input data in assessing agricultural nutrient management in China?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Integrating chemical fertilizer data with manure input data allows for a comprehensive assessment of total nutrient inputs to cropland, facilitating accurate understanding of nutrient balances and management practices. This integration helps in establishing the county-level spatial variation of manure input proportions, crucial for effective nutrient management and environmental impact assessments.

Causal Consequence.Question: What could be the outcome of including chemical fertilizer input data in the analysis of manure nutrient inputs to cropland across different regions in China?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The inclusion of chemical fertilizer input data allows for the establishment of the county-level spatial variation of the proportion of manure input, providing a comprehensive understanding of nutrient management and environmental impact assessment across different regions in China.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of spatial distribution variations of manure nutrient inputs on agricultural policy-making in China?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The spatial distribution variations, which show lower manure proportions in Eastern China and higher in Western China, provide detailed insights that can guide policymakers in developing region-specific agricultural nutrient management policies and practices.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives of collecting national survey data on manure nutrient inputs to cropland across China from 2005 to 2014?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to provide a clear perspective for manure nutrient management in agricultural production and to support environmental impact assessment at the spatial level in China.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to quantify manure nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium inputs at the county level for various crop types?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Quantifying these inputs at the county level helps in understanding the spatial distribution of manure nutrient inputs, which is critical for developing effective nutrient management strategies and policies.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the intention behind combining manure input data with chemical fertilizer input data from a national survey?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intention is to establish the county-level spatial variation of the proportion of manure input, which provides detailed support for environmental impact assessment and agricultural nutrient management.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What steps are involved in organizing and categorizing survey data from over 6.6 million farmers to ensure the reliability of manure nutrient input statistics?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The farmers are divided into four groups according to crop type: cereals, fruits, vegetables, and others. The total manure nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P), and potassium (K) input to the cropland for each crop type is quantified extensively at the county level. This organization facilitates the accurate calculation of manure inputs for different crop types based on county-level statistical data.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can county-level spatial variation of manure nutrient input be established using survey data and statistical data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: County-level spatial variation is established by first calculating the manure inputs for different crop types based on county-level statistical data. This information is then combined with chemical fertilizer input data from a national survey, allowing for the determination of the proportion of manure inputs relative to total inputs at the county level.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What processes are followed to quantify the total manure nutrient input for different crop types at the county level?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To quantify the total manure nutrient input for different crop types at the county level, the survey data of farmers is first organized according to the type of crop. The manure N, P, and K inputs are then calculated and quantified extensively for each crop type. This quantification is based on statistical data collected at the county level.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies enable the accurate quantification of manure nutrient inputs at the county level for diverse crop types?
Enablement.Answer: The methodologies include dividing farmers into groups based on crop type and extensively quantifying the manure nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P), and potassium (K) inputs to the cropland for each crop type at the county level, followed by calculations based on county-level statistical data.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of chemical fertilizer input data enhance the assessment of manure nutrient management in agricultural production?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of chemical fertilizer input data allows for establishing the county-level spatial variation of the proportion of manure input, providing a clear perspective for manure nutrient management and environmental impact assessment at the spatial level.

Enablement.Question: What conditions enable the comprehensive collection of survey data from over 6.6 million farmers across a large geographic region like China?
Enablement.Answer: The conditions likely include a well-organized national survey infrastructure that systematically collects data on manure inputs and crop types at the county level, enabling detailed support for research and policymaking in agricultural nutrient management.

Expectation.Question: Why might the anticipated spatial distribution of manure nutrient inputs differ across various regions in China?
Expectation.Answer: The spatial distribution of manure nutrient inputs varies, with lower proportions in Eastern China and higher in Western China, which may be due to regional differences in agricultural practices, crop types, or farmer preferences.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using county-level statistical data in assessing the spatial variation of manure nutrient inputs in cropland?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of county-level statistical data is effective as it allows for the quantification of manure nutrient inputs at a detailed spatial level, which provides a clear perspective for manure nutrient management in agricultural production and aids in environmental impact assessments across different regions of China.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how data collection methods account for the spatial variation in manure nutrient inputs at the county level.
Assertion.Answer: The spatial variation of manure nutrient inputs at the county level was established by quantifying the total manure N, P, and K input to cropland for each crop type and combining this with chemical fertilizer input data from a national survey.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how a dataset could effectively support environmental impact assessments in agricultural nutrient management.
Assertion.Answer: The dataset provides a detailed description of the utilization of manure nutrients in agricultural areas throughout China, offering basic support for policymakers and researchers involved in future agricultural nutrient management and environmental impact assessments.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the data collection methods used for gathering national survey data on manure nutrient input in cropland across China.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection involved a national survey of over 6.6 million farmers from 2005 to 2014. Farmers were categorized by crop type (cereals, fruits, vegetables, and others), and manure nutrient inputs (N, P, and K) were quantified at the county level. Additionally, statistical data at the county level were used to calculate manure inputs for different crop types, and these were combined with chemical fertilizer input data to establish spatial variations of manure proportions.
